issues.description: Attribute name mismatch for the Ride class: the UML in the problem statement declares the second Ride attribute as "shortCode: char" (problem_statement.md) but the solution implements this attribute as "abbreviation: char" with getter getAbbreviation() (solution Ride.java). This naming difference can confuse students about the exact attribute name and expected getter (e.g., getShortCode() vs getAbbreviation()) and may lead to inconsistent implementations if students follow the UML literally.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute name consistent across artifacts. Either update the problem statement/UML to use "abbreviation: char" (and document getter getAbbreviation()), or change the solution and template to use the UML name "shortCode: char" and provide a getter getShortCode(). Ensure constructor parameter names and getter names match the chosen attribute name so students can implement exactly what the specification shows.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement defines a Ride attribute named 'shortCode: char' but the solution implementation names the corresponding field 'abbreviation' (with getter getAbbreviation()). This is a naming mismatch for the same conceptual entity (the ride's short identifier) and may confuse students when they try to map the UML attribute 'shortCode' to the code members.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the identifier consistent across artifacts. Either (A) rename the field and getter in the code to match the UML: change 'abbreviation' -> 'shortCode' and 'getAbbreviation()' -> 'getShortCode()' (also update constructor parameter names and usages in subclasses), or (B) update the UML/problem statement to use 'abbreviation' instead of 'shortCode'. Prefer option A to keep the UML as the source of truth for this exercise.
